comments.commentBody: It is now time for all who share Dr. Krugman's opinion to ask a bizarre and difficult question that i never could have imagined asking myself until recently. Is it morally acceptable to live in the richest country in history while our politicians vote to take food away from hungry children? some would insist on continuing to fight the mean-spiritedness for as long as it's possible. others are packing their bags. I'm sick to my stomach, and it's not from food poisoning or lack of nutritious calories. When the results lead to american deaths from malnutrition, I wish all those who voted for this could be charged with treason, and hang from the gallows. Because sadly, and for shame, many poor people are going to die in the richest country on the planet, one that exports surplus food all over the globe,  because of this callous hatred and utter lack of any empathy.

I moved to Australia - pretty severe gun use restrictions here, and yet somehow the big-government Orwellian apocalypse hasn't happened. People seem to be able to go about life just fine.

Re: John - the risk of death due to gunfire may be much lower than that of an automobile accident (or other accidents, depending on who you are), but that's kind of beside the point. We can, and should, reduce deaths from firearms while we work to solve our other problems - it's not like there's some rule that says we can only solve one problem at a time.

Plus there's a sense of trust that comes from living in a place with less antagonism, less violence, less vigilantism and even less negligence and delusion. I don't feel like my fellow humans are out to get me. My fellow humans don't feel the need to so easily facilitate self-defense through lethal means - trading a bit of their safety (and mine) for that possibility. We value the lives of those people who are unwilling or unable to be the "good guy with a gun."

Accidents still happen and people still make mistakes. Crimes still happen, there is still injustice. But I feel, at least, we gain a bit of mental health, and move one step away from suspicion and toward cooperation, when we reject the "mutually assured destruction" paranoia of "an armed society is a polite society."

I feel especially sensitive about the few profiting while the many suffer. On July 14, a guy in my infantry company died in Vietnam.

What?, you ask, fairly, has that to do with Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, employment, and the privileged few who ordain the nation's matters as opposed to the many who don't ordain anything.

George arrived in our company the morning of July 14 and that evening was in a body bag on his way home. I helped him off the resupply chopper, in his brand new fatigues with his nervous demeanor, and that night I called battalion to report him KIA.

The people who appointed matters in Vietnam were like unto the men and women in our House of Representatives: all about ideology and the whims of the few, but insensitive to what it meant.

They didn't have to be, then or now.

When George died in 1969 a minimum wage worker in the U.S. made the 2011 equivalent of $8.25 an hour. In 2011 that worker was making $7.25 while the cost of being alive has skyrocketed. If minimum wage workers in the U.S. had realized the increases our fewest citizens have seen since 1980 they'd be making $28 an hour. SNAP might not be a concern.

But 47 million Americans are on food stamps. Tens of millions make less $15,080 a year, or $3,400 below the federal poverty line for a family of three.

The board of directors running this corporate nation don't much care about the employees, George in 1969, or the workers now.

They're a club we aren't in or wanted in.

Understand it? Me either. The closest I can come  is to listen to my octogenarian parents, who are Tea Party stalwarts. Their basic logic is this: We scrimped and saved so that we wouldn't be a burden; why should we all pay for those who weren't careful, who were wasteful and profligate? Of course, my parents do receive Social Security...and Medicare...and worked during a time when the balance of generations was much different...but their argument is basically a moral one. Not that they aren't racist -- they are -- but they see moral failings in whites as well as blacks. They also have fear: fear that what they have saved will be taken away (through more taxes) and that the USA will devolve into a "welfare state" where hard work is not rewarded. In my parents' defense, they never took food stamps, unemployment, or any other type of what they would call welfare. Times were different from today. Today's Tea Party seems to be a demographic phenomenon: white senior citizens who did OK during their prime, never took "welfare," and don't consider Social Security or Medicare to be "government programs" but merely insurance programs that they paid into (which they did, but are reaping outsize benefits). Can anyone else explain the Tea Party? Is this about right?

History has demonstrated that, when power is concentrated, and sustained, things don't usually turn out too well.  That is why we have anti-trust legislation against monopolies, and time-limits on patents and copyrights.  Might I suggest, rather than a fixed-term limit on patents (the 20-years in W.A.Spitzer's comment), how about a fixed-amount limit on the resultant revenues, or a combination (e.g. 5 years or $50 million, whichever comes first).  Since most inventions build on prior inventions, this would ensure that the really good ideas would enter the public domain more quickly, accelerating the genesis of more good ideas.

I've never encountered much quite so entertaining as a nobelist economist waxing blue on social issues. I thought I was done for the evening after responding to your twin (which is Arnold, which Danny?), when, lo! -- another offering appears.

The court's decision on genes was eminently sensible, and one doesn't need to list kumbaya to appreciate it: what occurs in nature shouldn't be patentable; but what man invents out of whole cloth generally ought to be. New genetic combinations are a special case that really need to be parsed on a case-by-case basis.

These wonder-treatments don't just spontaneously generate as maggots in old wood: far from being the products of selfless souls operating solely for the benefit of man, they labor largely for lucre of one kind or another, then must attract billions in capital to build an industrially viable model. Direct rewards plus the establishment capital required must be RISKED by real people, and could well be lost. What allows all this to happen is the protection, at least for a time, of exclusive rights to exploit the value of what is invented. Without it, we're back to one Jonas Salk every 50 years.

Of COURSE such rights reinforce inequality. There is no equality between what Jonas Salk and I (so far) have contributed. To not acknowledge this is to argue for apportioning all production evenly across all people, irrespective of their output, or the need to incentivize world-class contribution. Heavens, what ARE you? A LIBERAL?

We already do invest in one another -- up through high school. No questions asked -- just assumed to be good to have an informed citizenry. But there is no selection process. Everyone can attend public school through 12th grade. College -- even public colleges -- have a selection process which leads to us investing in some of us -- not all of us. For me, that is only palatable if we also invest in the folks who don't get selected, such as the technical/vocational training Germany provides.

Public financing for college is morally right and economically beneficial. Public financing to train future plumbers, dry cleaners, and auto mechanics is also morally right and economically beneficial. We should either do both or neither.

We do, of course, have to be careful not to create what we have created in K-12 education -- a unionized system where the benefits of the teachers and its union takes precedence over the educational results of the children. We will need a voucher system to allow choice and competition.

While I appreciate the common sense of this argument (and the correct position that we should fund education publicly), it is too bad, indeed, that we can only seem to muster economic arguments to discuss the whys of higher education. Even intangibles are caught up in a discussion of "human capital," and while I appreciate Prof. Folbre's tongue-in-cheek reference to the relatively low worth of a degree in theatre arts (and by extension all the arts and humanities), I'm afraid the subtlety of her reference may be lost on some readers.

Need we defend learning -- in utilitarian terms -- that gives us nearly everything we hold dear in our culture?

Let us invest in one another, rather than investing in "the economy."

Leonard Piekoff would address this far more effectively (and perhaps would have a different perspective from my own), but the GOP (or Dem, for that matter) course(s) of action cannot be characterized as “Randian” in any sense.  Rand’s Objectivism maintains that the proper moral purpose of one's life is the pursuit of one's own happiness/rational self-interest, and that the only social system consistent with this morality is full respect for individual rights embodied in laissez-faire capitalism.  First, taking a long-term perspective, I don’t think that pursuing wealth as an overriding goal with no moral/ethical compass (as we seem to see so often today), while creating a deeply troubled underclass, is in any way acting in one’s rational self-interest; the wealth dichotomy will eventually tear apart society, and as we have seen elsewhere in the world, a society rife with unrest cannot be in the self-interest of any but perhaps the weapons manufacturers.  Second, certainly no part of our government can lay claim to allowing, or even encouraging, the pursuit of laissez-faire capitalism; the government has more meddling layers of favoritism and special interests than there are stars in the galaxy.  Feel free to quote Orwell or Huxley, who sit laughing over their heavenly poker game as they observe our predicted earthly shenanigans; regardless of the popular rhetoric, our government, at the point of a gun I might add, has never allowed Rand to enter the equation.

I've definitely seen students purposely do poorly in school to lash out at parents, or sometimes to get their attention, and I've also known students to deliberately fail classes of teachers they disliked. Every student is different, and needs different responses to this type of behavior... but often what needs to happen is for the parents to back off if they're over-involved or to get more involved if they've been distracted by something else (divorce, problems with a sibling, etc.).

In the case of the unlikeable teacher (it would have been helpful for me to learn this before the age of 29, for example), sometimes it serves the student better just to buckle down and do the work, because the failing grade seldom hurts the teacher, but usually hurts the student and his or her future.
